info.title: About MACRS Depreciation
info.description: MACRS (Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System) is the primary method used to determine depreciation deductions for U.S. federal income tax purposes.

methods.title: Depreciation Methods:
methods.200DB: 200% Declining Balance (GDS): Provides the highest tax deductions in the early years
methods.150DB: 150% Declining Balance (GDS): Provides higher deductions than straight-line but lower than the 200% method
methods.SL: Straight Line (SL): Deducts the same amount each year (except the first and last year)

salvage_note.title: About Salvage Value:
salvage_note.description: Under MACRS rules, depreciation calculations typically assume a salvage value of $0. However, this calculator allows you to enter an estimated salvage value to more accurately reflect the asset's actual value. When a salvage value is entered, depreciation will stop when the book value reaches the salvage value.

faq.title: FAQ
faq.description: Common questions about MACRS depreciation calculation.

items.title: What is MACRS depreciation?
items.description: MACRS (Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System) is the depreciation method required by the IRS for most business assets placed in service after 1986. It allows businesses to recover the cost of assets over a predetermined recovery period.

items.title: Which depreciation method should I use?
items.description: The 200% Declining Balance method provides the highest deductions in early years, making it ideal for maximizing early tax benefits. The Straight Line method spreads deductions evenly and may be required for certain asset types. Consult with a tax professional for your specific situation.

items.title: What is a recovery period?
items.description: The recovery period is the number of years over which you can depreciate an asset. Common periods include 5 years for computers and cars, 7 years for office furniture, and 27.5 years for residential rental property. The IRS determines the recovery period based on asset classification.

items.title: Do I need to consider salvage value?
items.description: Under MACRS rules, salvage value is typically assumed to be $0 for depreciation calculations. However, you can enter an estimated salvage value in this calculator to see when depreciation will stop if you plan to sell or dispose of the asset.

items.title: Is this calculator IRS-compliant?
items.description: Yes, this calculator uses depreciation rates from IRS Publication 946. However, for official tax filing, always consult with a qualified tax professional or CPA to ensure compliance with current tax laws.
